questions.question:
Question 1: Which of the following RNA viruses has an 8 segmented genome with its site of replication 
being the nucleus?
questions.explanation:
Influenza virus has an 8 segmented genome. Its site of replication is the nucleus, unlike other 
RNA viruses. Influenza virus belongs to the Orthomyxoviridae family. Most DNA viruses replicate in the nucleus, except pox. Most RNA viruses replicate in the 
cytoplasm, except retroviruses and orthomyxoviruses. Examples of segmented viruses (ARBO): • Arenavirus (2 segments) • Rotavirus (11 segments) • Bunyavirus (3 segments) • Orthomyxovirus (8 segments) The image below shows the segmented genome seen in the influenza virus (Orthomyxoviridae)

questions.question:
Question 2: A microbiologist working on influenza virus in a lab, observes reversal of hemagglutination. 
What is this phenomenon known as?
questions.explanation:
406 
Sold by @itachibot Elution is the process of reversal of hemagglutination and the release of the virus from the red cell 
surface. Influenza virus contains two surface antigens: • Hemagglutinin (HA) - causes RBC agglutination; facilitates viral entry into cells • Neuraminidase (NA) - an enzyme that destroys the receptor HA uses to bind to RBCs causing 
elution/reversal of hemagglutination. Hence, it is also called a receptor destroying enzyme (RDE).

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following statements is true regarding antigenic drift?

options.a: There is a gradual sequential change in antigenic structure
options.b: It doesn’t account for the periodic epidemics of influenza
options.c: The new antigens thus formed are totally unrelated to the previous antigens
options.d: Antibodies to the predecessor viruses do not neutralise the new variants

questions.explanation:
Antigenic drift causes a gradual sequential change in antigenic structure. It accounts for periodic epidemics. This property forms the basis for the development of annual 
influenza vaccines. Antigenic variation is a property of influenza viruses by which it alters the antigenic structure on 
its surface and thus avoids a host immune response. It is of two types - Antigenic shift and

questions.question:
Question 4: Which of the following organisms is represented by the given form of replication? 399 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given image shows the replication of influenza virus. Stages of replication: • Attachment, penetration, uncoating- the virus is internalized by receptor-mediated endocytosis • Transcription and translation- Viral transcription occurs in the nucleus. The mRNAs are 
produced from viral nucleocapsids. • Viral RNA replication- Viral genome replication is accomplished by the same virus-encoded 
polymerase proteins involved in transcription. • Maturation- The virus matures by budding from the surface of the cell.

questions.question:
Question 5: You receive multiple patients from a poultry farm presenting with fever, dyspnea, cold, and 
cough. You suspect an outbreak of Avian flu. Which of the following virus strains causes the 
same?
questions.explanation:
H5N1 is a strain of avian influenza. Transmission occurs only from birds (e.g. poultry). Recombination occurs 
in pigs. Human-to-human transmission is very rare. It causes flu-like symptoms and can cause severe respiratory illness. Option A: H1N1 causes swine flu Option C: H3N2 causes Hong Kong flu Option D: H2N2 caused a pandemic in 1957

questions.question:
Question 6: A 4-year-old girl with a history of fever, rhinorrhea, sore throat, and myalgia presented with 
multiple episodes of vomiting and seizures. She was diagnosed with Reye's syndrome. Which 
of the following is incorrect about the most likely etiological agent?

options.a: Virus shedding is present before symptoms begins
options.b: 5-12 years is a high risk group

questions.explanation:
The most likely etiological agent in the given case of Reye's syndrome is the influenza virus. 
Children <5-years, especially those <2-years of age are at the highest risk of serious 
complications related to influenza infection. Other high-risk groups for influenza include 
adults 60 years of age, persons with chronic diseases, persons who are immunocompromised. Option A: The virus is shed in respiratory secretions a day before the onset of illness and for 3-4 
days thereafter. Option C: Birds, especially aquatic birds act as reservoirs of influenza viruses. Option D: Secondary attack rate is 5-15%. 408 
Sold by @itachibot Note: Reye's syndrome is precipitated by the interaction of a viral infection (such as 
influenza) with salicylates. Therefore, aspirin is not given to pediatric patients with influenza and 
influenza-like illness.

questions.question:
Question 7: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the OPD with complaints of headache and drowsiness since 2 
days. He had a history of fever, ear pain, and difficulty in swallowing for 1 week. On 
examination, you see the following. Brudzinki's sign is positive. What is the most likely 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with fever, parotitis, headache, drowsiness, and positive Brudzinki's 
sign is suggestive of meningitis secondary to mumps. Mumps is caused by the mumps virus and is characterized by fever, bilateral or unilateral parotid 
swelling which may be tender. Parotitis can present with ear pain and difficulty in swallowing. It 
usually resolves in a week. Meningoencephalitis/aseptic meningitis can occur before, along with, or after parotitis. Most 
commonly, it manifests 5 days after parotitis. It can present with headache, neck stiffness, and 
drowsiness. Complications of mumps: • Aseptic meningitis or meningoencephalitis • Epididymo-orchitis- Usually unilateral. Seen in post-pubertal males • Oophoritis • Other complications include pancreatitis and myocarditis Note: Non-mumps parotitis can be caused by: • Epstein-Barr virus - causes infectious mononucleosis • Coxsackievirus - causes herpangina • Parainfluenza virus - causes croup

questions.question:
Question 8: A 9-month-old child is brought to the OPD for MMR vaccine. Which strain of mumps virus is 
used in the same?
questions.explanation:
The strain of mumps virus used in the MMR vaccine (Measles, Mumps, Rubella) is the Jeryl-Lynn 
strain. The virus is attenuated by serial passage in embryonated eggs and grown in chick embryo 
fibroblast culture. Note: The schedule of MMR vaccine as per the National Immunisation Schedule is from 9 
completed months to 12 months. (can be given till 5 years of age).

questions.question:
Question 9: A mother brings her 5-month-old baby to the casualty with complaints of fast breathing and 
poor feeding. She also gives a history of fever, cold, and cough for 3 days. On examination, 
nasal flaring and expiratory wheeze are present. Which of the following statements is false 
about the viral etiology of the same?

options.a: The cytopathic effect is syncytium formation
options.b: Ribavirin is the drug of choice
options.d: It is the most important cause of bronchiolitis

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of bronchiolitis caused by the respiratory syncytial virus 
(RSV). Palivizumab is given for RSV prophylaxis in high-risk infants such as premature babies, 409 
Sold by @itachibot immunocompromised infants, etc. Option A - The characteristic cytopathic effect is syncytium formation (multinucleated giant cell). Option B - Inhaled ribavirin is the drug of choice. Option D - RSV causes upper and lower respiratory tract infections in infants, and is the most 
common cause of bronchiolitis from ages 6 weeks to 6 months. It can cause pneumonia and 
tracheobronchitis and is common during winters and monsoon.

questions.question:
Question 10: An unimmunized man presents with fever, malaise, and an erythematous rash starting from 
behind the ears and progressing to the face and trunk. Given below is an image of lymphoid 
tissue taken from this patient. What pathological finding do you see here?
questions.explanation:
Warthin-Finkeldey cells are seen here. These are multinucleate giant cells, which are found in the 
lymphoid tissues of patients with measles. The cytopathic effect of measles consists of multinucleate syncytium formation with numerous 
acidophilic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions, as shown in the image below. Option B: Warthin-Starry stain is used to detect spirochetes and to stain H. pylori and B. henselae Option C: Langhans giant cells are seen in tuberculosis Option D: Aschoff giant cells are seen in rheumatic fever

questions.question:
Question 11: 402 
Sold by @itachibot A 3-year-old boy with no prior immunization history presents with fever, cough, and coryza. 
On examination of the buccal mucosa, you see the following. Which stage of the disease is 
this finding seen in?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows Koplik’s spots present in measles. They are seen during the prodromal 
phase of the illness. Koplik's spots are small bluish-white ulcerations on the buccal mucosa opposite to the first and 
second lower molars and are pathognomonic of measles. They contain giant cells, cytoplasmic and 
intranuclear inclusions, and virion components. They can involve the entire buccal mucosa and 
fade as the maculopapular rash develops. 410 
Sold by @itachibot Stages of measles: The natural history of measles has 3 stages as follows: • Prodromal stage - It begins 10 days after infection and lasts until day 14. It consists of cough, 
coryza, redness of eyes, lacrimation, photophobia, vomiting, and diarrhea. Koplik's spots appear 
in this stage. • Eruptive stage - A dusky, red maculopapular rash appears. It starts behind the ears spreads 
downwards to the trunk and lower extremities. Antibodies appear in this stage and are detectable 
by IgM ELISA. The symptoms such as fever and rash usually resolve spontaneously or go on to 
develop complications. • Post-measles stage - Weakness and weight loss may persist. The infection may become chronic 
and cause secondary infections such as cancrum oris, candidiasis etc. The image below shows Koplik's spots The image below shows the characteristic maculopapular rash in measles 411 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following disease has the highest mortality once clinically manifested?
questions.explanation:
Rabies is a vaccine-preventable, zoonotic, viral disease. Once clinical symptoms appear, rabies is 
virtually 100% fatal. Spread of rabies: • Centripetal spread - • The virus enters the peripheral neurons, it moves via retrograde fast axonal transport towards 
the spinal cord or brainstem a.k.a the central nervous system (CNS) at a speed of up to 250 
mm/day. • Once within CNS, it spreads quickly to other regions in the CNS through fast axonal transport. It 
infects neurons primarily, but may rarely infect astrocytes. • Centrifugal spread - After CNS infection is established, it spreads along the sensory and 
autonomic nerves to: • Salivary glands • Adrenal glands • Skin Rabies virus replicates in acinar cells of the salivary glands and is secreted in the saliva of rabid 
animals that serve as vectors.

questions.question:
Question 13: A 26-year-old pet-groomer was brought to the casualty with a history of breathlessness, 
excessive agitation, and restlessness. His bystanders give a history of progressive behavioral 
change and he had a fever, sore throat, and generalized weakness 1 month back. On 
examination, pulse was 100 bpm, SpO2 was 98% on room air. Which of the following 
samples will not be preferred to detect the etiological agent? 403 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario is highly suggestive of rabies. Corneal impression smears are not 
performed, as they are of low diagnostic yield. Laboratory diagnosis of rabies is performed by the following methods: • Antigen detection - Direct immunofluorescence (IF) from specimens of : • Skin biopsy from the nape of the neck including hair follicles. Rabies antigen is present in 
cutaneous nerves at the base of hair follicles. It is the most sensitive and specific test. • Corneal smears were previously used. They are not used anymore as they are of low diagnostic 
yield. • Viral isolation- Intracerebral inoculation in mice can be attempted from the brain, CSF, and 
saliva. • Antibody demonstration from serum and CSF. • Viral RNA detection by RT-PCR . • Postmortem examination of brain tissue samples- demonstration of Negri bodies. 412 
Sold by @itachibot

Question 14: An officer of the Indian Forest Services is bitten by a rabid fox while on duty. Which of the 
following statements is true about the etiological agent?

options.a: The incubation period is 4 to 5 days

questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of infection with the street form of rabies virus. Street rabies 
causes disease. All mammals are susceptible to rabies. Cattle, cats and foxes are highly susceptible, whereas dogs 
and humans have intermediate susceptibility. Differences between street rabies and fixed rabies: Street rabies

questions.question:
Question 15: A 23-year-old man was brought to you with a history of fever, behavioral changes, and 
seizures. He is foaming at the mouth and is unable to ingest liquids. The patient was admitted 
to the ICU, however he died soon after. Post mortem brain samples showed the following 
finding. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given image showing Negri bodies and the case scenario of fever, neurological symptoms 
like seizures and altered sensorium, hydrophobia (due to painful muscle contractions during 
swallowing liquids), and hypersalivation are suggestive of encephalitic rabies. Negri bodies are eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions in neurons that are composed of rabies virus 
proteins and viral RNA. These are commonly observed in Purkinje cells of the cerebellum and in 
pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus. Their presence is a characteristic pathologic finding in 
rabies. The image below shows Negri bodies: 413 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 16: Babes nodules are seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Babes nodules are seen in rabies. Mononuclear inflammatory infiltration in the leptomeninges, 
including microglial nodules are called Babes nodules. The most characteristic pathologic finding in rabies is the Negri body. These are eosinophilic 
cytoplasmic inclusions in brain neurons that are composed of rabies virus proteins and viral RNA. 
The image given below shows Negri bodies.

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following statements is false regarding rabies vaccination?

options.d: Vaccinating pigs is helpful in disease control

questions.explanation:
414 
Sold by @itachibot According to the Updated Thai Red Cross Regimen (2-2-2-0-2) for post exposure prophylaxis, 
reconstituted rabies vaccine is given as follows: • 0.1 ml intradermally • Sites - two sites at the same visit. It is given in both the deltoids • Schedule - Days 0, 3, 7, and 28 Healthy dogs, cats, or ferrets may be confined and observed for 10 days. The dosage of equine rabies immunoglobulin (eRIG) is 40 IU/kg while that of human anti-rabies 
immunoglobulin (hRIG) is 20 IU/kg body weight. PrEP regimens for individuals of all ages are as follows: • Three intramuscular or intradermal vaccine doses on days 0, 7, and 21 or 28. 415
